textEng: And now...
Ah, success. Gather around.
Whoaaaa.
WHOOOOOAAAAAAA!
Ahem. Hello, human. Red here.
Everyone on the Moon loves humans!
And so! Do! I!
(A crash.)
Ouch!

textKor: 진정. 인간 놀람. 그리고\n시끄러워. 귀 먹먹하다.
textEng: Calm down. Human startled.\nAnd too loud. Ears ringing.

textKor: 응, 아직 오류가 많아서 언제\n신호가 끊어질지 모름.
textEng: Yes. Numerous errors\nmaking signal unsteady.
Say hello, Cello.\nI will translate.
Wait. (Zz) Breaking.... (Zzzz)
First prototype, prone\nto malfunction.

textKor: 켜지고 꺼지는 타이밍도 설정이\n안 되고. 어쩔 수 없음.
textEng: Settings for turning on\nand off not yet an option.

textKor: 지금 슬픔은 견디고, 다음에\n켜지면 제일 먼저 인사해.
textEng: No need to be sad. Be\nthe first to say hello next.
Wonder how you’ll pull it off.

textKor: 하아아아아아음. 으, 시간이\n언제 이렇게. 일하기 싫어.
textEng: Yaaaawn. Ugh, look at the\ntime. I don’t wanna work.

textKor: 너희는 일할 때 무슨\n생각 하면서 청소해?
textEng: What do you guys think of\nwhen you work?
I do not think. I do.
Sing?

textKor: 맞아, 첼로 경이 노래하면 내가\n자막을 만들어서 같이 불러.
textEng: That’s right. When Sir Cello\nhums, I make up the lyrics.
Like this!

textKor: 해괴한 호수는 차오른다!\n퍼 담고 굳히고 긁어 내자!
textEng: The filthy lake is swelling high!\nScoop it up and scrape it dry!

textKor: 짝짝이 팔다리 비틀어진 등허리!\n달 뒤편의 아래의 구석을 지키는!
textEng: Uneven arms, twisted back!\nNo room here to cut some slack!
We are the cleeeaners\nof the Moon!

textKor: 아. 잠시만. 켜진 것\n같음. 불 들어오네.
textEng: Ah. Wait. Seems to be on.\nLight is on.
Say hello, Sir Cello.
Sir Cello! Say hi!!
(Zz) Not again, (Zzzz)
Hmm. (Hums excitely)
Hmm-hmm.
Hmm-mm-hmm-mm.
Human! Ah, ahem.\nRed here.
(Pattering footsteps.)
I stole the transmitter while\nEdison had her back turned.

textKor: 달나라를 보여 주고 싶어서.\n빨리! 시간이 없어!
textEng: I wanted to show you around.\nQuick! We don’t have time!

textKor: 우선 저어기 (발걸음이 탁탁탁\n빨라진다) 보이는 건 꿈 공장이야!
textEng: First there’s (footsteps quicken)\nthe Dream Factory.

textKor: 정말 아름답지? 대부분 인간의\n눈에는 보이지 않지만.
textEng: Beautiful, right? It’s usually\ninvisible to the human eye.

textKor: 하지만 뭉치를 볼 수 있다면\n이 공장도 볼 수 있을걸?
textEng: But if you can see Dot,\nI bet you can see it too.
Those sparky friends over\nthere are the Moon moths.

textKor: 흐흐. 내 발밑엔 땅바닥...\n그리고 짠. 크레이터.
textEng: Hehe. And the ground under\nmy feet... and ta-da. The crater.

textKor: 검은 호수 같지? 다들 끔찍하다고\n싫어하지만, 난 뭐랄까,
textEng: Looks like a black lake, right?\nNo one likes it. But me?
Well, looking at it somehow...\nsoothes me.
What are you doing?

textKor: 뭐 하긴? 인간한테 달나라\n구경 시켜 주고 있다.
textEng: What does it look like? I’m\nshowing the human around.
What. What!
What! Why are you\ngiving me that look!
Showing what.
The Factory... the moths...\nthe ground... the craters...

textKor: 지구에선 달 뒤편이 안 보이니까,\n궁금하지 않을까 하고....
textEng: And I thought they’d like to see\nthe dark side of the Moon...
Visual information\ncannot be transmitted.
What? You’re kidding!
Hand it over.

textKor: (작은 한숨 소리) 아아. 싫어어.\n인간이랑 더 이야기할래.
textEng: (Sigh) Noooo. I wanna talk more.

textKor: 떨어뜨리기라도 했으면 어쩔 뻔\n했음? 크레이터에 빠트렸으면?
textEng: And if you dropped it?\nIf it fell into a crater?
Hand it over.
I need to check for damages.
(Small sigh)
Hey Edison, Sir Cello!

textKor: 아니, 글쎄, 동쪽 구역 청소를\n맡은 치커리 영감이 말이야.
textEng: You know Old Man Chicory\nthat cleans the east section?
Says he saw a GHOST\nyesterday.
Ghosts are illusions.
Or temporary changes in\ntemporal lobe brain waves.
Are not.
False.
Do not indulge him, Sir Cello.

textKor: 치커리 영감 정도라면\n환시를 볼 나이도 됐음.
textEng: Hallucinations. Not uncommon\nfor a man of Chicory’s age.

textKor: 자러 가던 달나방 떼를\n귀신으로 착각했을 수 있음.
textEng: May have mistaken a swarm\nof Moon moths for a ghost.

textKor: 그런 거겠지? 안심이\n되는 것 같기도 하고.
textEng: Yeah? Boy, that’s a relief.
I’m sure glad the four of us\nare together though.
‘Cause real or not,\nghosts are SCARY.
Wait.
Four?
Wait...? There’s no way......!
AAAAHHHHHHHHHH!

textKor: 해괴한 호수는 차오른다!\n퍼 담고 굳히고 긁어 내자!
textEng: The filthy lake is swelling high!\nScoop it up and scrape it dry!

textKor: 짝짝이 팔다리 비틀어진 등허리!\n달 뒤편의 아래의 구석을 지키는!
textEng: Uneven arms, twisted back!\nNo room here to cut some slack!
We are the cleeeaners of the Moon!
God, my back is killing me.
Perhaps.
But not due to cleaning.

textKor: 네가 쉬는 동안 허리 펴기 귀찮\n다고 구부정하게 앉아서 그럼.
textEng: You slouch during break times\nrather than sitting straight.
But it’s been work, work,\nwork all day with an\nextra scoop of work!

textKor: 쉴 때엔 너무 피곤해서 웅크리고\n있어야만 살 것 같단 말이야.
textEng: I slouch because I’m just too\npooped to do anything else.
I can’t take it anymore.\nEdison! Sir Cello!

textKor: 이대로는 안 되겠어. 멋진\n어른 인간들을 본받자.
textEng: We gotta take a leaf from\nhumans and that book of theirs.
We’ll need a ‘home’,\nand ‘work hours’!
Hmm?

textKor: 이 모닥불 구덩이를 우리의\n‘집’이라고 정하는 거야.
textEng: We’ll call this bonfire pit\nour ‘home.’
Then?
Then we assign ourselves\nworkloads for each day.

textKor: 크레이터에서 퍼다 나른 폐기물\n로 구덩이를 열 개 채우면
textEng: Once we fill ten pits with\nMoon filth from the craters,
we’re off the clock\nand get to go ‘home’!

textKor: 별자리가 반의 반 뼘만큼 공전\n했을 때 다시 출근하는 거지!
textEng: We’ll go back to work\nwhen the constellations\nmove... THIS much.

textKor: 괜찮은 것 같음. 한번 해 봐.
textEng: Sounds interesting.\nSuggest you give it a try.
No, WE will.
All three of us!
Affirmative.

textKor: 집이 생겼어. 따끈한 모닥불...\n잘 구워진 돌 의자.
textEng: We have a home now.\nA warm bonfire... a toasty stone chair.
It is nice.
You think something’s missing?
Guess it’s pretty empty.
It is the dark side of\nthe Moon. Always empty.
But that doesn’t mean\nour souls have to be empty.

textKor: 우리, 집을 꾸며 보는 건 어때?
textEng: Why don’t we give\nhome decor a shot?
Hmm.
... Good. Will fetch more pebbles.
Edison, Sir Cello!
Time to remember\nthe good old factory days.

textKor: 가장 기억에 남는 하루 말하기 대회를 열자.
textEng: Let’s vote for\nA Day to Remember!
A Day to Remember?

textKor: 꿈 공장 직원이었을 때 봤던 인간들의 하루 중
textEng: We’ll look back on humans\nand their days that\nwe saw in the factory.

textKor: 가장 기억에 남는 하루를 말하고, 우리끼리 우승자를 정하는 거다!
textEng: We’ll each share a memory,\nthen decide which day\nwas the most memorable!
Ahem. I’ll start.
It was the first kid\nI was assigned to.

textKor: 그 꼬마는 차곡차곡 용돈을 모아 무려 일 년을 매진했고
textEng: She saved her allowance\nfor a whole year.

textKor: 결국 '띠부띠부 씰'을 전부 다 모으는 데 성공했다!
textEng: And got her hands on\na full set of baseball cards!

textKor: 학교 친구들의 부러움을 한몸에 받았지. 기세등등하던 꼬마의 하루가 아직도 생생해.
textEng: Her friends worshiped her.\nI still remember\nhow triumphant she was.
Edison, you’re up next.

textKor: ... 돌이켜보면 한 여덟 명 정도의 인간을 담당했던 것 같은데.
textEng: ... I was assigned\na total of eight humans.

textKor: 그중 두 번째 맡았던 인간이 떠오른다. '노벨 물리학상'을 받는 게 그의 가장 절실한 꿈이었고,
textEng: The second human. His\nlifelong ambition was to\nwin the Nobel Prize in Physics.

textKor: 그래서 난 그가 여덟 살일 때부터 일주일에 한 번씩 '노벨 물리학상'을 받는 꿈을 보내 주었었다.
textEng: So ever since he was eight,\nI sent him that very dream\nonce a week.

textKor: 그리고 그가 어른이 된 이후 정말 '노벨 물리학상'을 수상했음.
textEng: And once he became of age,\nhe did win the Nobel Prize.
Nobel Prize? What’s that?

textKor: 노벨'이란 인간이 다른 인간들에게 주는 상장이라고 함. 인간들에겐 아주 의미 있는 모양이다.
textEng: A human named Nobel\nhands out awards. They mean\na great deal to humans.

textKor: 기쁨에 겨워 빙글빙글 돌던 그의 춤사위를 단 하루도 잊어 본 적이 없음.
textEng: I have never forgotten\nhis celebratory dance.

textKor: 첼로 경은? 약 마흔 명의 인간을 담당하지 않았어?
textEng: And you, Sir Cello?\nDidn’t you look after,\nlike, 40 humans?
You must have lots of stories!

textKor: 오와! 오와! 잠시만, 이걸 우리가 어떻게 이겨!
textEng: Whoa! Whoa! How are\nwe supposed to top that?

textKor: 마, 말도 안 돼. 거짓말! 거짓말!
textEng: Get out. You’re joking!

textKor: <가장 기억에 남는 인간의 하루 말하기 대회> 우승자는... 첼로 경인 걸로 하자...
textEng: And the winner of A Day to\nRemember is... Sir Cello.
Red, a question.
Back then.
Why suggest sending Dot to Earth?

textKor: 우리가 뭉치를 우주로 던지기\n직전, 뭉치가 했던 말 기억해?
textEng: Right before we launched Dot into space,\ndo you remember what they said?
Over there... Dreams...\nSomething like that.

textKor: ‘저기엔 나를 꿈으로 삼아 줄\n다른 존재가 있을지도 몰라요.’
textEng: ‘Over there, someone may\nwant me as their dream.’
Yeah, right! That.
Dot,
Dot... can dream.
Dream?

textKor: 폐기물에서 태어난 괴물....\n맞아, 유쾌한 존재는 아니지.
textEng: A monster born of filth...\nThey are not usually welcome.

textKor: 그 검은 눈을 보고 있으면 희망...\n같은 무언가가 느껴졌어.
textEng: But when I looked into Dot's eyes,\nI felt hope... or something like it.
They were dark but certain.

textKor: 그걸 인간에게 보내면, 그 인간은\n분명 행복해질 것 같았어!
textEng: So I thought if a human met Dot,\nthey would become happy for sure!
And Dot’s cute, in an ugly way.
(A string of high staccatos,\nakin to laughter.)

textKor: 나의 전구 머리로는 해독할 수\n없는 난해한 감상. 뭉치가 ‘귀엽다’니.
textEng: Difficult to wrap my lightbulb head\naround this notion. Dot, ‘cute.’

textKor: 에디슨, 그런 너는 내 제안을\n왜 흔쾌히 수락한 거야?
textEng: So why’d you give me\nthe okay then, Edison?
In spite of it being reckless,\nstupid, and dangerous?
(Bickering noises.\nRed grumbling.)
Because I believed in you.

textKor: 너의 계획은 무모하고 멍청하고\n위험하기까지 했지만, 따뜻했다.
textEng: Your plan was reckless, stupid, and\ndangerous. But still warmhearted.

textKor: 네 불꽃 대가리가 밝혀 낸 가능성에\n희망을 걸어 보고 싶었어.
textEng: Wanted to pin my hopes on the\nwarmth your flame-head illuminated.

textKor: ...... 인간을 보고 싶다는 열망이\n이성을 이겨 버린 후이기도 했고.
textEng: ...... Also, my desire to see a human\novercame my rational side.
Edison! Wait up!
Huff... huff... Moon butterflies\ncame at me all of a sudden.
Moon-butterflies.\nWinged insects inhabiting\nedge of craters.
Reacting to what?

textKor: 그, 청소 구역 표시해 둔\n표지판 말이지.
textEng: Well, you know that sign that\nmarks all the cleaning spots.

textKor: 내가 불 조절을 실수해서\n조금 태워 버렸다!
textEng: I messed up and it\nkinda caught on fire.
.....Kinda? Certain?

textKor: 크흠, 조금! 그래서 종이가\n타닥타닥 타들어 가는데...
textEng: Just a smidge! The paper\nwas burning away when...
A swarm of Moon butterflies\ncame at me from the south!
Before I knew it I was\nsurrounded by them.
Wave after wave of silver\nrippling before my eyes.
Confusing, but beautiful!
Moon butterflies and their\nshimmering stardust flight.
....Edison? Where you going?
My lab.

textKor: 달나비가 불에 타는 것에\n반응하는 이유를 탐구해야겠다.
textEng: Will investigate why Moon\nbutterflies burn in fire.

textKor: 첼로 경은 왜 언어로 말하지 않게 된 거야?
textEng: ...Why doesn’t Sir Cello\nspeak with words?

textKor: 첼로로 아름다운 소리를 내던 인간?\n아! 첼로 경이 마지막으로 맡았던\n인간은 음악가였구나!
textEng: The human that created beauty with\nhis cello? Oh! So your last\nhuman was a musician!
An undeniable prodigy?\nOh my......

textKor: 그런데 거만했다니! 모든 천재 인간들은\n콧대가 높단 말이 있더라니, 역시였어!
textEng: But arrogant! So it’s true.\nGeniuses do look down on everyone else!
Oh, Sir Cello! The transmitter is blinking.

textKor: 뭉치의 인간도 듣고 있을지 몰라.\n내가 첼로 경의 말을 번역해 줄까?
textEng: Dot’s human might be listening.\nShould I translate for you?

textKor: 인간, 내가 첼로 경에게 왜 말을 하지\n않게 되었는지를 물어보고 있었어.
textEng: Human, I was asking Sir Cello why\nhe no longer speaks in words.

textKor: 너에게도 이야기를 공유하고\n싶대! 번역해 줄게. 나만 믿어!
textEng: He’d like to share the story\nwith you as well! I’ll translate,\nyou can count on me!

textKor: 그러던 어느 날, 첼로 경의 인간은\n사고로 손을 크게 다치고 말았어.
textEng: One day, he hurt his hand\nreal bad from an accident.

textKor: 저런.... 오랜 기간 끝에 회복했지만\n다치기 전 실력은 되찾을 수 없었대.
textEng: He got better but could\nnever play like he used to.

textKor: 다른 이들은 그의 몰락을 지켜보며\n연민하기도, 유희처럼 즐기기도 했어.
textEng: Everyone watching his\ndownfall sympathized,\nbut they laughed too.
Horrible melodies played in\nthe human’s nightmares.

textKor: 날카로운 말들로 가득찬 세상\n속에서 그를 위로할 수 있던 소리는\n첼로 선율만이 유일했지만,
textEng: Cello strings were the only source\nof comfort in a sea of cruel noises,

textKor: 이젠 사랑하던 음악마저 그의\n현실만큼이나 지옥이 되어 버렸고
textEng: but the music he once loved\nwas now as stark as reality.

textKor: 끝끝내 인간은 자신의 삶을\n연주하기를 포기해 버렸대.
textEng: And in the end... the human\ngave up playing his life.

textKor: 첼로 경은 그의 음악을\n사랑했던 만큼 깊게 슬퍼했어.
textEng: Sir Cello mourned, as he\nwas in love with his music.
And while navigating\nthat grief he found music.
I shall play a tune vastly\nmore beautiful than\nwords alone, just for him.
Says Sir Cello.

textKor: 할 이야기가 있다 다들\n원을 이루게 모여 보도록.
textEng: Announcement. Everyone\ngather around in a circle.
Oooh, Edison’s got\nhot gossip! What’s up?
Went to clean the crater\nin the corner yesterday.
A dark place, left unkempt.

textKor: 도구를 준비 하던 중, 크레이터 안에서\n무언가 뻗어 나온 것을 목격.
textEng: Witnessed something peeking\nout of the crater while preparing.
A pale, thin hand\nresembling a branch.

textKor: 마디가 기이할 정도로 길게 뻗은 그 손이\n나에게 인사를 건네고는 사라졌어.
textEng: Elongated fingers waved at\nme before disappearing.

textKor: 직후에 크레이터 안을 확인해\n봤지만... 아무것도 없었음.
textEng: Scanned the crater immediately...\nfound nothing.

textKor: 남은 것은 심연과 같은 어둠 뿐.
textEng: All that was left was\ndarkness like an abyss.

textKor: 하하! 에디슨. 잘못 본 거 아니냐?\n연구하느라 눈이 나빠졌나 본데!
textEng: Get outta here, Edison! Need\nnew glasses or something?
Like that’s supposed\nto scare me. No way!

textKor: 아냐, 첼로 경! 내 불이\n흔들리는 건 추워서야. 크흠.
textEng: No, Sir Cello! My fire’s\nflickering cause it’s CHILLY.

textKor: 이, 일부러 무서운\n음악 연주하는 거지? 그만!
textEng: A-Are you playing creepy\nmusic on purpose? Stop it!
Hmm? I can’t find Edison.
Sir Cello, know where Edison is?

textKor: 또 틀어 박혀서 연구하고 있군. 며칠째\n필라멘트 코빼기도 안 보이잖아!
textEng: Stuck in the lab again. We haven’t\nseen hide or filament of her for days!
Wait, does that mean...
We don’t have to come\nto work every day?
You knew already? No way!
Then I’ll take a day off\nfrom cleaning too.
I’ll just go home and... well...
....Do what?
...You’re right. Life on the\nMoon with no work is boring.

textKor: 일이라고 부르지만, 사실은\n너희와의 산책과 다름 없으니까.
textEng: I call it work, when actually it’s\njust a nice stroll with you guys.
And I don’t have to think about\nsad things when I’m working.
....Ugh. Get those notes\nshaking, Sir Cello!
Today’s a day for cleaning\nthe small crater in the east.

textKor: 에디슨, 첼로 경. \n내가 여기 있는 줄은 어떻게 알았어?
textEng: Edison, Sir Cello. What are\nyou doing all the way here?

textKor: 아직 청소 덜 끝난 거 아니었어?
textEng: I thought you were\nstill cleaning?

textKor: 내 눈동자에 비치는 네 모습을 봐, 레드.
textEng: Your reflection in my eyes, Red.
Flickering. About\nto be snuffed out.
... Thinking of the human child?
Oh...! Didn’t mean to\nworry you. But you’re right.

textKor: 오늘같이 우주가 얼어붙은 듯\n고요한 날엔 그 애가 생각나서 말이야.
textEng: When it’s silent like the\nuniverse has frozen over,\nI’m reminded of him.

textKor: 시린 물 한가운데로 스스로\n걸어 들어간 그 애가.
textEng: The boy that walked into\nthe freezing water willingly.
Yeah. Time has passed but\nI haven’t forgotten a thing.

textKor: 그 애의 하루를 들여다볼 때면\n느껴지던 깊고 깊은 외로움이.
textEng: That deep deep loneliness I felt\nwhenever I peered into his day.
If I could have been a\nmoment of warmth for him...
Would things be different?\nCould he have lived on?
These thoughts keep\nme up even now.
... You can always confide in us.

textKor: 그런 후회를 하는 건\n크레이터를 치우는 이 공장\n아래의 모두가 마찬가지니까.
textEng: We all have regrets.
(Rustling of wings from afar.)
(Squeaking of feelers.\nMoon moths or butterflies?)
(Rapid flapping of wings.)
Hmm. Is this on? (Zzzz-)
Do you copy, human? ... Seems\nto be malfunctioning. Oh well.
Will need to make adjustments\nafter observing the pattern\nin which it turns on and off.
In the meantime.

textKor: 이곳 달 뒤편에는 인간의\n흥미를 돋울 만큼\n흥미로운 이야기는 없다만.......
textEng: Here on the dark side, there’s not\nmuch to pique a human’s interest......

textKor: 역시, 인간에 대한 이야기를\n해 주는 편이 좋으려나.
textEng: Suppose a story about\nhumans will suffice.

textKor: 나도 직원 시절 관찰했던\n인간 하나가 있었다.
textEng: I too observed a human\nduring my days as a worker.\nOne that studied the stars.

textKor: 망원경이 발명된 지 얼마\n지나지 않았던 시절,\n별을 탐구하던 인간이었지.
textEng: During a time when binoculars\nhad just been invented,\nthe human was a scholar of stars.
The human would gaze at the\nnight sky with her lover.

textKor: 하지만 그의 아름다운 애인은\n갑작스러운 사고로 생명을 잃었다.
textEng: But her lover lost their\nlife in a sudden accident.

textKor: ‘나중에 저 별에서 다시\n만나는 거야.’ 라는 말을 남기고.
textEng: ‘That star is where I’m\nheaded after I die’,\nwere his last words.

textKor: 인간은 그들이 다시는\n만날 수 없다는 걸 알았다.
textEng: The human was not aware\nof the name of the star.

textKor: 그래서 인간은 연구에 더\n몰두했지. 매일, 매 시간, 매 초를.
textEng: And so she threw herself into her work.\nEvery second of every hour\n... of every day.
Her obsession over\nreuniting with her lover\ngrew and grew. Until...

textKor: 나는 그의 상실을 온전히 이해하고\n있다고 판단했고,
textEng: I assumed that I understood\nthe entirety of her loss.
And so I made mistakes.
Foolish mistakes, again\nand again, every night.
...... I cannot bring myself\nto tell you more.
But know this:

textKor: 그 실수를 반복하지 않으려고\n개발한 것이다. 인간, 너와의 송신기를.
textEng: This transmitter was made so as not to\nrepeat the same mistake, human.

textKor: 대화를 통한다면...\n무지는 언젠가 극복될 수 있으니까.
textEng: As the only method of overcoming\nignorance… is to converse.
What if.
What if?

textKor: 만약에, 아주 투명한 영혼과\n순수한 마음을 가진 어느 인간이
textEng: What if a human, one with a\ntransparent soul and a pure heart,

textKor: 우주 비행사가 되어\n달의 뒤편에 착륙한다면 어떡하지?
textEng: becomes an astronaut and lands\non the dark side of the Moon?
What if they discover\nour beautiful factory,
And us, cleaning up filth?

textKor: 우리는 숨어야 하려나?\n아니면 인사를 건네야 할까?
textEng: Should we hide? Say hello?

textKor: 인간 또한 강한 탐구욕을 가진 종족.
textEng: Humans possess\na strong sense of curiosity.

textKor: 그는 분명 다가와 우리에게\n많은 질문을 쏟아 낼 것.
textEng: Highly likely that they will\napproach and ask questions.

textKor: 불꽃 머리를 화려하게 뽐내고\n있으면 눈에 띄겠지? 분명해!
textEng: My flaming head will catch their\neye, right? I’m sure of it!

textKor: NASA에 대서특필될 수도! 불꽃\n소년, 인간의 마음을 뜨겁게 데우다!
textEng: Maybe I’ll end up in the papers!\n‘Flame Boy Warms Up Human’s Heart!’

textKor: 아니, 그 전에 인간의\n표피를 뜨겁게 데울 듯하다.
textEng: Rather, your presence will\nburn the human’s skin.

textKor: 인간이 화상 입을 수도.\n인간의 외피는 우리의 생각보다 연약함.
textEng: Human may acquire a burn.\nTheir exteriors are far more\nfragile than we think.

textKor: 그들은 우주복 없인\n이곳에서 살아남을 수 없음.
textEng: They cannot survive here\nwithout spacesuits.
What if your flame were to burn\na hole through their spacesuit?
(Cue Beethoven’s Pathétique.\nA startling cacophony.)
Regardless, an emergency\nprotocol seems necessary.
Excuse me. I need time\nto come up with one.
It was a valid question, Red.
......That doesn’t make\nme feel any better!
Human. Humaaaan.

textKor: 오늘따라 잠이 오질 않아서\n에디슨 몰래 송신기를 켜 봤어.
textEng: Couldn’t sleep, so I snuck\naround Edison to turn this on.
Testing, one two three.\nCan ya hear me?

textKor: 음... 마지막으로 꿈 제작을\n담당했던 아이가 자꾸 떠오르는 것 있지.
textEng: Hmm… I can’t stop thinking about\nthe last human I took care of.
My last human.
You know, he really\nwas a sweet kid!

textKor: 친구들에게 마지막 남은 반찬을\n항상 양보할 정도로 마음이 넓었고,
textEng: Always sharing his food with his friends,

textKor: 지나가는 고양이와 인사하기 위해\n선뜻 주저앉아 손을 내밀\n정도로 경계가 보드라웠어.
textEng: Always squatting down\nto say hi to a passing cat.
But the world wasn’t sweet to him.

textKor: 원래 그렇게 이기적인 세상인 걸까,\n그 아이에게만 박했던 걸까?
textEng: Is it always that way, or\nwas the kid just unlucky?

textKor: 약해서? 인간 세계의 기준으로\n‘가난한 자’에 속해서?
textEng: ‘Cause he was weak? ‘Cause he was\n‘poorer’ than other humans?
‘Cause he didn’t have\nadults to hide behind?

textKor: 모르겠어. 이해할 수 없는\n아주 비겁한 이유였다고 생각해.
textEng: Don’t know. I bet it was a\nreally cowardly reason.

textKor: 그 아이를 에워싼 겨울도,\n주변의 어른들도. 결코 그에게\n온기를 되돌려주지 않았기에,
textEng: The winter cold and the adults\naround him didn’t do jack for him.

textKor: 난 모든 경우를 생각하며\n그를 데워 주려 했지만\n내 온기는 닿지 않았어.
textEng: So I tried everything to make him\nwarm, but nothing reached him.
Was I just not smart enough?
Or is the Moon too far from Earth?
......It’s all my fault.

textKor: 그래서 난... 그를 위해\n더욱 강렬하고 뜨거운\n불이 되기로 결심했어.
textEng: So I… decided I’d burn even\nfiercer and hotter, just for him.

textKor: 혹시 모르잖아.\n그 애가 지금 먼먼 우주를\n떠돌고 있을 수도 있는 거잖아.
textEng: Who knows. Maybe that kid is wandering\nin space, far away from here.

textKor: 그렇게 우리가 언젠가\n만날 수도 있는 거잖아!
textEng: And maybe one day\nwe’ll run into each other!

textKor: 그때, 그때 비로소 그\n아이를 데워 주면 되니까.
textEng: And then I can finally\nwarm the kid up.

textKor: 그러니 인간, 그때까지\n내가 타오르길 응원해\n줘야 해! 그럴 거지?
textEng: So you better root for me to\nkeep burning on! Can\nI count on you?
Do you remember?

textKor: 삽이 땅 속 무언가에\n부딪혔을 때 말야.
textEng: When my shovel hit\nsomething in the ground.

textKor: 맞아, 네가 땅속 무언가의\n정체를 몰라 우리를 불렀잖아.
textEng: Yes. You had no idea\nwhat it was and summoned us.

textKor: 난 그 자원을 이리저리 보고,\n냄새를 맡고, 만져보고,\n또 핥아보기까지 했지.
textEng: I studied, smelled, touched,\neven licked the resource.
And my senses confirmed\nwhat I already suspected.

textKor: 이것은 달과 꿈 공장에 혁신을\n불러일으킬 신자원이라는 걸!
textEng: That this new resource would\nbring about innovation on the\nMoon and the factory!
I left at once to retrieve my\nequipment from the laboratory
to begin experimenting on\nhow to convert it into fuel.
But I returned to discover\nthe resource missing.

textKor: 달을 샅샅이 뒤져보았지만\n낌새도 없이 사라져 있었음.
textEng: I searched the Moon\nbut it hadn’t left a trace.

textKor: 그때만큼 내 감정이 요동쳤던\n때를 찾기는 쉽지 않아.
textEng: My emotions had never\nbeen more intense.
With that, I return to my lab.\nUntil the next time.
(Pitter-patter of footsteps grows faint.)
No, we made the right call\nby not telling her.

textKor: 그 대단한 신자원이 고작\n‘얼음’이었다는 걸\n알았다면 에디슨은...
textEng: If Edison ever found out that\nher grand resource was just ice...
We did too! You remember\nhow excited I was.

textKor: 에디슨은 그 실망과 충격을 영원히\n극복하지 못할 수도 있다고.
textEng: Edison may never get\nover it for the rest of time.
Hehe. True.

textKor: 이미 녹아 없어진 얼음을 찾아\n헤매는 에디슨의 뒷모습도\n재미있었지!
textEng: It was pretty funny watching Edison\nfreak out over the ice disappearing.
Alright. I’ll lay off...
It’s days like these\nI miss being a worker.

textKor: 돌아갈 수도 없는 걸 그리워하면\n네 마음만 아픔. 일해라, 레드.
textEng: No point in missing\nwhat cannot come back.\nGet to work, Red.
Still!
Still.

textKor: 그때는 우리가 사랑하는 인간들에게\n사랑스런 꿈을 보내 줄 수 있었어.
textEng: Back then we could send dear dreams\nto the humans dear to us.

textKor: 꿈을 제조하기 전 그들의\n다채로운 하루를 재생해\n감상하던 업무는 매일의 낙이었지!
textEng: Nothing beat catching up on\nwhat they did each day\nbefore making dreams!

textKor: 재수없는 공장 놈들이 우리를\n무시하지도 않았고 말이야.
textEng: And those factory shucks\ndidn’t look down on us.
...True.

textKor: 경이로운 속도로 진화하던\n그들의 기술을 관찰하는\n것 역시 즐거웠다.
textEng: It was a pleasure observing their\ntechnology develop so rapidly.

textKor: 파이프 오르간과 반도체 칩,\n놀라울 만큼 정교했음.
textEng: Pipe organs and semi-conductive\nchips, all incredibly intricate.

textKor: 지성과 집념의 집약체였지.\n아직도 기억 속에 생생하다.
textEng: Beacons of intellect and will.\nI remember them clearly.
Right, then we never would\nhave met. But don’t you still miss it?
But we already have met.
And I am fonder of you two\nthan you are aware of.
Now, back to work.
Whoa. Whoa!
(Scuffling sounds)

textKor: 제대로 들은 것 맞지, 첼로 경?
textEng: Did I hear that right, Sir Cello?

textKor: 안녕, 인간! 오늘은 첼로 경이\n발을 잘려서 다시\n이어 붙여 주고 왔어. 칠칠맞긴!
textEng: Hi, human! Today Sir Cello\nsawed off his foot, so we had\nto put it back. What a clutz.
He’s fast asleep now.

textKor: 인간, 첼로 경이 말 대신 첼로\n선율로 소통한다는 것 알지?
textEng: You know Sir Cello speaks\nin cello strings, right?

textKor: 실은 원래 말을 할 수 있었대.
textEng: But he used to talk.
Actually... he still can!
But he chooses to be\nunderstood through music.
You see, Sir Cello’s\nfinal human was a cellist.
And music was what made\nthe human's life bloom.

textKor: 그가 살아가던 이유도,\n사랑하던 모든 것도 음악이었어.
textEng: He lived for music,\nand loved with music.

textKor: 사고로… 음악을 연주하는 능력을\n잃게 되었을 때마저도
textEng: After the accident...\nhe had to give it up.
Yet music was still his\nconsolance and escape.

textKor: 첼로 경이 그의 인간을 잃게 된 건
textEng: But eventually...
Words took him away\nfrom Sir Cello.

textKor: ... 물론! 인간들의 언어는 대부분\n아름답고 동그랗지만, 가끔은 정말\n날카롭고 끔찍해지기도 하거든.
textEng: … They are often round\nand beautiful, but at times\ncan be sharp and terrible.
And can hurt, and hurt until you just...

textKor: ... 그래서 첼로 경은 음악을 언어로\n삼아서, 자기 마지막 인간을\n기억해 나가고 싶은 거래.
textEng: So Sir Cello wants to speak\nthrough music, and remember\nhis final human with it.
Words hurt, and words lie.
But with music...\nyou just have to feel!
Feel it as it is.
Clear and alive.
Man, Sir Cello sure is cool.
Hey, guess what?

textKor: 인간들은 우리가 사는\n달에 참 관심이 많대!
textEng: Humans are really interested\nin this Moon of ours.

textKor: 그리스의 신화에서는\n달을 관장하는 세 명의\n여신들이 있다고 믿었대.
textEng: The Greek myths said three\ngoddesses looked over the Moon.
Artemis dealt with the crescent moon,\nSelene the full moon,\nand Hecate the waning moon.
WAY too cool and romantic.

textKor: 그리고, 한국에서는 달에서\n토끼가 방아를 찧는다고 믿었대.
textEng: Well, in Korea they believed\nrabbits lived on the moon.

textKor: 지구에서 보이는 달의 앞면을\n보며 그런 상상을 한 거야!
textEng: They came up with that just by\nlooking at the Moon’s surface!

textKor: 그러게... 이젠 과학의 발전으로\n신화나 동화를 믿는 인간이\n흔치 않아졌어.
textEng: True... science has made it\nrare for humans to believe in\nmyths or fairy tales.
It’s kinda disappointing.\nNo, very disappointing.
I disagree.
Storytelling to make sense of\nthe world is commendable.
But their dedication to the truth,

textKor: 바로 내가 인간을 사랑하고\n궁금해하는 이유 중 하나다.
textEng: is what I love to explore about humans.
Edison, you good?

textKor: 레드, 넌 너의 소년이\n우주를 여행하리라 믿지.
textEng: Red. You believe your boy\nis traveling through space.
Yeah.
I believe my human\nis gone for good.

textKor: 그가 사랑하던 여자 인간이 죽었을 때,\n난 그가 느끼던 고통을\n‘불가피한 과정’으로서 이해하지 못했다.
textEng: When the woman he loved\ndied, I did not understand his\ngrief was ‘a natural process.’

textKor: 꿈속에 그녀의 조각들을 잔뜩 심어\n두면 그가 분명 기뻐할 줄 알았고.
textEng: I thought planting her in\nhis dreams would give him joy.
I believed he would be\nhappy once more.
I was a fool.

textKor: …… 모든 인간은 상실을 겪으며,\n그것을 지나오는 과정은\n반드시 필요하단 걸.
textEng: ..... All humans go through\nloss, and grieve over it.

textKor: 그 상실감을 피해다니며 영원한 환상을\n거닐다 보면 깨어나야만 하는 현실이\n점차 초라하고 끔찍해진단 걸.
textEng: But avoiding that grief and\nwandering in a fantasy\nonly makes reality worse.
I did not know at the time.

textKor: 현실이 견딜 수 없어진 그는…\n결국 그녀를 따라갔다.
textEng: He could not cope with\nreality... so he followed\nin her footsteps.
... I killed him.

textKor: 내가 보내 준 꿈들이 그를 죽게 한 거야.
textEng: My dreams killed him.
I know now.
And I want him here.
I want him back.
You said your human\nliked stars, right?
Affirmative.

textKor: 나의 소년은 저어어어기\n파란 별을 여행하고 있다.
textEng: My human kid is traveling that\nblue star waaaay over there.
So your human’s\nsomewhere over...

textKor: 저어어…기 가느다랗게 빛나는\n노란 별. 아마도 그 언저리를\n여행하고 있을 거야!
textEng: There. That faint yellow star.\nHe’s probably traveling there!
With the woman he loved!
Hey, look! It just winked at us!
...... Thank you, Red.
Humans make\nirrational choices at times.

textKor: 발화기관이 아직 작동하지 않는\n태아와 대화를 나누고,
textEng: They speak with feti whose\nvocal chords are yet to operate.

textKor: 가장 절망적인 상황에서도\n아름다움을 좇으며 기쁨을 느낀다.
textEng: And look for beauty\nin hopeless situations,
despite not fully grasping\nthe true concept of beauty.
Irrationality. A puzzle\npiece that does not fit,

textKor: 묘하게 앉아 바라보고\n싶은 인간의 그 기묘한 특성.
textEng: and a human trait that makes\none want to contemplate it.

textKor: 그래, 어쩌면 그들이\n비합리적이기에 나를 그토록\n매료시킨 것일지도 모르지.
textEng: Yes, perhaps it is their irrational\nways that charmed me so.
But are you aware, Sir Cello?

textKor: 가끔은 그들을 온전히 이해할\n수 없을지도 모른다는\n공포에 마비된다.
textEng: The fear that I may not understand\nthem fully paralyzes me at times.

textKor: 왜 그때... 그런 사고를 했으며\n그러한 선택을 했는지.
textEng: Why… why they made\nsuch a choice back then.

textKor: 답 없는 메아리처럼 끊임없이\n짐작할 수밖에 없고, 당최\n이해도 납득도 되지 않을 때.
textEng: When all that is left is to ponder\nlike an echo with no reply,
I freeze.

textKor: 정말 그렇게 생각하나? 우리는 영원히\n그들을 이해할 수 없다고?
textEng: Is that truly what you think?\nThat we will never understand them?
… Perhaps our world is far too simple.

textKor: ...... 그런 게 중요하지 않다면\n대체 무엇이 중요한 거지?
textEng: …… If those are not\nof import, then what is?

textKor: 정말 이해하기 위해서는 이해하지\n못한 채로 받아들여야 한다고?
textEng: True understanding occurs when one\nembraces without understanding?
Embrace without understanding?
A sentence that contradicts itself.
Embrace the contradiction itself...
Boy. You really like embraces, huh.

textKor: (첼로 경이 연주를 시작한다.\n달의 새들이 모여드는 소리가 난다.)
textEng: (Sir Cello’s music. The rustling of\nMoon birds flocking together.)
(The dreamy harmony of bird chirps.)
See that space rock over there?
How long has it been drifting\nin this cold universe all alone?

textKor: 저 운석은 끝이 나는 것들의\n아름다움을 알고 있을까?
textEng: Does it know how beautiful\nit is that all things must end?

textKor: 어제까진 나의 인간 아이도\n그렇게 우주를 떠돌고 있기를 바랐었어.
textEng: Up ‘til yesterday, I hoped my human kid\nwas floating through space like that.

textKor: 오래 오래 떠돌다 보면 언젠가는\n만날 수 있을지 모르니까.
textEng: I thought maybe someday\nhe could wander right into me.
But...

textKor: 이젠 놓을래. 포기하는 게 아니야.\n그냥, 인정하는 거야.
textEng: I’m letting go now. Not\ngiving up. Just facing facts.

textKor: 슬픔을 애써 희망으로 바꿔 왔지만,\n이건 그 애를 위하는 길이 아니었어.
textEng: I’ve tried to be hopeful instead of\nsad, but this isn’t right for him.
Because.... because.

textKor: 그 애가 살아간 찰나의 시간이\n너무나도 눈부셨거든.
textEng: That split second of his life\nshined so bright.

textKor: 그 반짝임은 달에 있는\n나에게까지 닿을 정도였어.
textEng: So much that its light\nreached me on the Moon.

textKor: 나는 그 애의 고유한 반짝임을\n지켜 주고 싶어. 그러니 나는.
textEng: I want to protect\nhis special light. So I,

textKor: 기억해야만 해. 그 아이가 어떻게\n시작되었고, 어떻게 끝났는지.
textEng: I have to remember. How he\nbegan, and how he ended.

textKor: 끝과 함께 하나의 이야기로\n완성되었던 아이의 아름다운 인생을.
textEng: His beautiful life that drew to\na close, a complete story.
So I’ll be letting go.
But there’ll always be\na lil’ pang in my heart,
and sometimes saltwater\nwill leak from my eyes.
But that’s okay. Right, Edison?
Were your head not made\nof flames, I would pat it.
I will settle for your shoulder instead.

textKor: 다가갈 수 없고 곁에 있을 수 없는\n내 자신을 많이 원망했어.
textEng: I hated myself for not being\nable to be near you.
But... if you’d known me.\nIf we’d been friends,

textKor: 너는 내가 자책하는 걸 바라지\n않았을지도 모르겠다는 생각을,
textEng: it occured to me that you\nmight not have wanted this.
Me blaming myself.
You know,

textKor: 점점 어두워져가는 네 꿈을\n보면서도, 네가 꺼져 가고 있다는\n생각을 한 적은 한 번도 없었어.
textEng: your dreams turned darker, but I never\nimagined you were petering out.
You were as warm as\na strong flame to the very end.

textKor: 살고 싶다는, 살아 있는 존재들의\n끈질긴 본능만으로는
textEng: Just the will, and the\ndogged instinct to live

textKor: 또 내가 아주 멀리서\n보내 주었던 꿈들만으로는
textEng: and the dreams I sent\nfrom far far away

textKor: 네 온기가 끊어진 것을\n막을 수 없었던 거야.
textEng: weren’t enough to stop\nthat warmth from petering out.

textKor: 그래, 나의 탓이 아니었다는\n걸... 이제는 알 것 같다.
textEng: Yes, I know now... that\nit wasn’t my fault.
It was hard to cope\nwith all the bad luck.

textKor: 사실 나는 어른이 된 너의\n모습을 궁금해하고는 했는데.
textEng: I used to wonder what you\nwould be like as an adult.
And I always will.
I don’t blame you.

textKor: 하지만 너무 약했던 너를\n아무렇지 않게 짓눌렀던\n그들의 몹쓸 강함이 밉고
textEng: But I resent that strength that\ncrushed you like it meant nothing

textKor: 너를 당연히 지켜 줘야 했던\n사회란 게 그토록 허술한\n울타리일 뿐이었다는 사실도 밉고
textEng: and the careless fence of a society\nmeant to keep you safe

textKor: 차디찬 겨울밤, 손난로\n하나 건네 주던 사람이\n하나 없었다는 것도 너무, 너무 미워.
textEng: and that no one was there to hand you\na pair of mittens on that cold winter night.

textKor: 넌 그 조그만 온기로도 다시\n타오를 소년이었다는 걸 알아서.
textEng: Because I know that warmth would have\nbeen all it took for you to light up again.
Ohhhhhh. Oh.

textKor: 왜냐하면... 난 진짜\n어른이 된 네 모습이
textEng: Because... I wanted to know\nwhat you’d be like as an adult.
I really really did.

textKor: 그래, 레드가 그런 생각을\n하게 된 게 기특하면서도……
textEng: Yes, I feel proud of Red\nfor thinking so. And also...
Much relieved.
Ah? Mm... As for me...
It seems I will\nforever berate myself.
For what happened\nback then, but also...
Entirely feeling this exhausting\nand agonizing emotion
and so remembering him,\nis my way of caring.
... I have something\nself-serving to say.
I do not want humans to die.
Mm. It sounds even more\nself-serving out loud.

textKor: 모든 생명의 삶은 한 편의 이야기.
textEng: Every life is a single story.

textKor: 한 명이라도 그 이야길\n귀 기울여 듣고 있다면,
textEng: They say even if just one person is\nreally listening to your story,

textKor: 우린 살아갈 힘을\n잃지 않을 수 있다고 한다.
textEng: you will never completely lose\nthe will to live on.

textKor: ... 그래, 우리 세 명이\n서로의 청자가 되어 주었듯이.
textEng: ... Yes. Like how the three of us\nlistened to each other.
... I want humans to know.
That we are listening.

textKor: 매일 한 명 한 명의 인간을 위해\n꿈을 만드는 한 명 한 명의\n꿈 공장 직원들이 있으며...
textEng: That there are dream factory workers\ncrafting dreams for each\nperson, for you.

textKor: 비록 그들을 더는 볼 수 없게 되었음에도,\n그들의 하루하루를 응원하고\n사랑하는 달 뒤편의 청소부들이 있다고.
textEng: That there are cleaners on the dark side\nof the Moon who root for\nand love all their days.

textKor: 우리만으로는 충분하지 않을지라도...\n우리의 목소리가 너무 작아\n미처 닿지 못할지라도.
textEng: That even if we may not be\nenough... even if our voices\nare too weak to reach so far.
Even so.
We are still here...
And we want them to live on.
Do you guys ever\nwanna go to Earth?

textKor: 갑자기? 지구? 갈 방법이\n없는데 그걸 왜 상상해야 하지?
textEng: Earth? Now? Why think on it when\nwe have no means of going?
Fine, whatever. It’s not like\nI was curious or anything!
… Earth is full of mysteries.

textKor: 그러나 우주에서 나는 돌만큼이나\n내 연구에 실용적인 자원은 없다.
textEng: But the Moon offers resources\nof actual use for my research.
Though human scholars and\ntheir ideas do intrigue me.…
Sir Cello wants to learn\nthe melodies of Earth.

textKor: 특히 바람 소리나 빗소리처럼\n지구의 자연이 내는\n다정한 울림들이.
textEng: Like the gentle tunes of\nnature, blowing in the wind\nor pouring in the rain.

textKor: (달 나비의 맑은 종소리 같은\n날갯짓이 먼 발치에서 들린다.)
textEng: (The beating of Moon butterfly\nwings rings from far away\nlike clear bells.)

textKor: 동감함. 달에서만 특수히 공명하는\n선율들이 나 역시 그리워질 거다.
textEng: I concur. I too would miss the unique\nmelodies echoing on the Moon.

textKor: 나는 정말 가 보고 싶지만,\n지구에는 인간을 비롯한\n생물이 너무 많아.
textEng: I’d give anything to go. But there\nare too many creatures on Earth.
Too, too…. TOO many!

textKor: 내 불길이 뜨거워 누군가 다칠지도 몰라.
textEng: My flames could hurt any one of them.

textKor: 비좁지만, 척박해서 오히려\n널찍하게 느껴지는 달이\n나에겐 딱인걸.
textEng: The Moon, though cramped\nand barren, might in fact be\njust wide enough for me.
Oh, and I can run anywhere\nand everywhere here.
I can ruuuuuuuuuuun…\n(Running footsteps grow quieter.)
Human! We’re here to...\nwell... say our goodbyes.

textKor: 뭉치의 눈을 통해 틈틈이\n바라보았던 넌 정말 아름답고\n따스한 마음을 가진 인간이었어!
textEng: From what we’ve seen through\nDot’s eyes, you’ve been such\na beautiful and warm human.
Yes, it was an honor to meet you.
We love you!\nEveryone loves you!
Sincerely and forever, from\nthe dark side of the Moon!

textKor: 첼로 경 역시 영광이었대.\n많은 인간에게 우리가\n그들을 사랑한다고 전해 달래!
textEng: Sir Cello also says it was an\nhonor. He says to tell many\nhumans that we love them!

textKor: 이런. 구식 회로를 사용해서\n그런가. 고장 나기 직전.
textEng: Oh. The transmitter is about\nto break down. Perhaps it is\nthe outdated circuits.

textKor: 걱정 마. 머지않아 달나라\n송신기 ver 2.를 출시할 것이다.
textEng: No need for concern. Soon an updated\nversion will be released.
‘Two-way communication’ is\non the horizon. Wait, human.
Then will this one... turn off soon?
Yes.
Human....... human..!\nI’m really gonna miss ya.
(Cello tuning noises sound\nlike the clearing of a throat.)
Nah! Let’s end things with a laugh!

textKor: 그러니 우리 셋이 함께 특별한\n이별 노래를 불러 줄게. 알았지?
textEng: So here’s a serenade\nfrom the three of us.

textKor: 크흠, 크흠! 잘 들어야 해!\n인간에게도 익숙한 노래일 거야!
textEng: Ahem! Listen up!\nYou might know this song.
Sir Cello, cue music!
♫So long, farewell\nAuf Wiedersehen, goodbye♫
♫Goodbye, goodbye...... goodbye!♫
